column2: Which company is your Service Provider agreement contracted with?
column3: What is/are the service(s) you are contracted for?
column4: In which state/territory/province is your contract based?
column5: What best describes the primary territories of your routes?
column6: What percentage of your deliveries are to residential addresses versus business addresses?
column7: How many additional Service Provider agreements does your company have?
column8: When did your company begin operations under a Service Provider agreement?
column9: Approximately what  percentage of your revenues comes directly from your Service Provider contract.
column10: On a scale of 1-5, how would you rate your company's financial health over the past year?
column11: Over the past year, have your year-over-year revenues:
column12: Over the past year, have your year-over-year profit margins:
column13: What are the major finical challenges you face?
column14: On a scale of 1-5, how would you rate your company's operational constancy over the past year?
column15: Over the past year, has your year-over-year operational efficiency:
column16: On a scale of 1-5, how would you rate your company's current operational efficiency?
column17: What are the major operational challenges you face?
column18: How many routes in an average week are dispatch to service your contract?
column19: Have you expanded or reduced your routes in the past year?
column20: How many drivers are used to support your contract in an average week?
column21: How many helper/jumpers are used to support your contract in an average week?
column22: How many managers are used to support your contract in an average week?
column23: How many administrative & executive (non-operations) positions does your company employ?
column24: How would you rate the overall health of your business one year ago?
column25: How would you currently rate the overall health of your business?
column26: How would you rate your prediction for the overall health of your business one year from now?
column27: Compared to the past year, how do you feel about the upcoming year in terms of business growth?
column28: Compared to the past year, how do you feel about the upcoming year in terms of operational challenges?
column29: Compared to the past year, how do you feel about the upcoming year in terms of profitability?
column30: How confident are you in the stability of your contract in the coming year?
column31: How confident are you in the stability of the company you contracted with in the coming year?
column32: What are your top three concerns for the future of your business? [First concern]
column33: What are your top three concerns for the future of your business? [Second concern]
column34: What are your top three concerns for the future of your business? [Third concern]
column35: Are you considering expanding, maintaining, or reducing your routes in the upcoming year?
column36: Do you believe the demand for delivery services in your region will increase, decrease, or remain the same in the next year?
column37: Can you share a specific challenge you've faced in the past year and how you addressed it?
column38: Describe a recent success story or a significant milestone your company achieved.
column39: If you could suggest one change to improve contractor relations, what would it be?
column40: Are there any upcoming industry changes or trends that you believe will impact your business positively or negatively in the next year?
column41: Share an experience that exemplifies your relationship with the company your contract is with.
column42: What's one thing you wish outsiders knew about the challenges and rewards of being a Service Provider contractor?
column43: Please provide any feedback you have regarding this survey.

column38: We’re treading water and did not end up in bankruptcy
column39: FedEx needs to realize that if they want A+ top shelf, contractors with top notch quality drivers, and uphold a A+ image and quality delivery they need to pay more on contracts
column42: The contractors are controlled as managers, directly employed by FedEx, but assume all the risk and responsibility of a business owner. Contractors have very little Control of how to run their businesses or improve on their businesses. FedEx continually audits our payroll they claim is for compliance like we are not controlled legally by our local state and governments. I feel FedEx uses this Payroll audit as their inside line on our costs and give us Just enough Un contracts to keep our heads above water

column3: Residential Pickup and Delivery;Business Pickup and Delivery
column13: Debt Service (i.e. SBA Loans, equipment loans, equipment leases, etc.);Equipment Costs (i.e. price of vehicles, scanners, iPads, etc.);Fuel Expenses;Pay and Salary Increases;Professional Services (i.e. legal representation, book keeping, etc.);Vehicle Maintenance and Repair Costs (i.e. mechanic rates, cost of parts, etc.);Vendor Service Pricing (i.e. cost of payroll provider, route management subscriptions, etc.)
column37: With the massive increase in package size & weight we can't fit as many packages in each truck and are penalized for being inefficient.  We run extra trucks for overflow every day and are penalized for being inefficient.  We've had two guys out with injuries for several weeks a piece because of heavy packages (one with hernia that still needs surgery, second one with shoulder tear that needs surgery)
column39: Increase pay.  The job is NOT what it used to be.  Package size/weight is ridiculous now and we can't afford to pay these guys what they're worth with current contract rates!
column40: Negatively.... FedEx getting more contracts for huge packages.  We know what senders are paying FedEx to ship these packages.  How about cutting us in on a FAIR share!
column41: We do a good job and have a good working relationship with our local management.  It is engineering and upper management that are not allowing us to be paid well based on how they build our contracts.  We should not be breaking even every week, we should be paying our guys a salary based on what this job requires....and we can't.
column42: It's all challenges at this time.  HUGE packages, high turnover, increased costs of doing business....and contracts that stay the same or get decreased....EVERY YEAR.  I have advised people to not become contractors until FedEx starts making the contract actually worth something more than a break-even point.
column43: I'll continue to do these, but it sure doesn't seem like anything is changing.

column41: The day after the recent hurricane two managers with the contracted company said they would dispatch 8,000 terminal wide because of all the closures.
